# Draft:All The President's Elephants (Film)__disambig_1

All the President’s Elephants is an extraordinary 52-minute documentary showcasing the deep bond between a woman and a herd of several hundred wild, free-roaming, wild elephants known as The Presidential Elephants of Zimbabwe, adjoining Hwange National Park, Zimbabwe. It has been referred to as being profound, courageous and inspirational.
=Introduction=
All The President's Elephants is widely considered to be a remarkable documentary, released in 2012, which chronicles the life of Sharon Pincott, an Australian woman who leaves behind her high-flying life in Australia in 2001, while in her late-30s to protect, promote and monitor this 'presidential herd' of elephants in Zimbabwe, Africa, on a full-time, voluntary and primarily self-funded basis. It was commissioned by Natural History Unit (NHU) Africa and created by South Africa's [https://www.triosphere.tv/portfolio]Triosphere production company.
* Executive Director – Oloff Bergh.
* Directors - Richard Slater-Jones and Kira Ivanhoff.
* Producers – Kira Ivanhoff and Richard Slater-Jones..
* Cameramen - Riaan Laubscher, Dale Hancock and Don Percival.
Editor – Katherine Pienaar.
More Film Analysis
Historical and Factual Context
Key Themes in the Film
* Human-animal relationships
* Wildlife conservation.
* Personal sacrifice for a cause.
* Political instability and its impact on wildlife
Location
Hwange, Zimbabwe: The political and geographical setting of the film.
Awards and Nominations
Official Nominations for this documentary include – South African Film & Television Awards 2013: Best TV Wildlife Program, Best Director, Best Editor, Best Cinematographer. Official Film Festival Selections: Durban International 2012; Jozi South Africa 2013; Netherlands 2013; France 2013. At the Japan Wildlife Film Festival 2013 it won ‘Outstanding Contribution to Nature’ – with the judges commenting how “very moving” it was “to see how closely people and elephants can be mentally connected”, and expressing their respect and appreciation for Pincott’s elephant conservation work. It was also a finalist at the Sichuan TV Festival 2013 Gold Panda, China, for ‘Best Nature & Protection Award.’ Screen Africa described this documentary as “unforgettable” as well as “touching and profound”. Intrepid Explorer magazine called it “riveting” and “graphic and powerful”. When it screened on French television, its name was changed to The Elephant Guardian (La Gardienne Des Elephants). It also screened on television in various French-speaking countries including France, and also Poland, Hungary, South Africa and Australia. In 2016, it was a finalist in the International Elephant Film Festival, known now as one of the ‘World’s best elephant films’ from the previous 9 years – an event that involved both the United Nations and CITES.
Where Online to View Currently
All the President's Elephants is distributed by [https://www.offthefence.com/Brand/1871/all-the-presidents-elephants]Off the Fence production company and [https://www.etv.co.za/]South Africa etv. It is currently available for viewing on the [https://iwonder.com/titles/all-the-presidents-elephants-2d6551cde64d48211c6e202ccbd63bb2?srsltid=AfmBOoptLL8gpxVsjMSQ9MTXw9WYpzFGZjdRzE6eAG8SwODkB9YgzbR5]Iwonder.com online site, and also available for free viewing in all regions around the World on [https://stirr.com/watch/5831/all-the-president-s-elephants]Stirr.com.
